author: Nasiru Eneji Abdulrasheed
title: Starbucks Launches 'Borrow A Cup' Program to Cut Waste and Promote Sustainability
text:
In the heart of Seattle, a city known for its pioneering spirit and green initiatives, Starbucks has launched an ambitious pilot program, Borrow A Cup, aimed at significantly reducing waste and paving the way for a more sustainable future. Announced on February 16, 2024, this innovative scheme offers customers the opportunity to order their favorite drinks in reusable cups for a nominal $1 deposit. In a bold move towards sustainability, the coffee giant is not just stopping at reusable cups but is also spearheading changes in South Korea to eliminate single-use cups entirely.
A Step Towards Sustainability
Starbucks' Borrow A Cup program is not merely a test but a reflection of a growing trend towards environmental responsibility. By allowing customers to return their cups for a refund and additional rewards points, Starbucks is incentivizing the shift away from disposable culture. This initiative is a critical part of the company's broader goal to cut its global waste production by up to 50% by expanding such programs. In South Korea, the commitment goes even further, with the coffee chain setting an ambitious timeline to phase out single-use cups altogether, in favor of reusable options.
The Challenge of Disposable Cups
The disposable paper cups market, valued at US$ 8,714.28 million in 2021, is projected to reach US$ 11,039.14 million by 2028, growing at a 3.4% CAGR. This growth is fueled by increasing regulations promoting the use of paper-based packaging solutions to minimize the plastic footprint. Despite being a sustainable alternative to plastic, disposable paper cups are challenging to recycle due to their inner plastic liner. The COVID-19 pandemic initially dampened the market's growth due to manufacturing disruptions. However, as fast-food joints paused their 'Bring Your Own Cup' campaigns in favor of disposable cups, demand surged. With rising vaccination rates, the market is poised for significant growth in the coming years.
Looking Ahead
Starbucks' initiative in Seattle and South Korea represents more than an environmental program; it is a step towards transforming the cultural landscape of consumption. By tackling the issue of waste at its source, Starbucks is setting a precedent for other corporations to follow. The success of the Borrow A Cup program and the phased elimination of single-use cups in South Korea could potentially trigger a domino effect, inspiring similar actions across the globe. As the world grapples with the twin challenges of waste management and environmental sustainability, programs like these offer a beacon of hope and a roadmap for the future.
In conclusion, Starbucks' Borrow A Cup program is a testament to the company's commitment to sustainability and its willingness to lead by example. Amidst a backdrop of rising disposable cup demand and environmental concerns, such initiatives offer a promising path towards reducing global waste and fostering a culture of responsibility and innovation. As the program unfolds, it will be intriguing to watch its impact on consumer behavior and the broader industry's approach to sustainability. The journey towards a greener future is paved with challenges, but with concerted efforts and innovative solutions, significant strides can be made in reducing our environmental footprint.

author: Vanessa Adame
title: IAAFA celebrates 80th anniversary, graduates more than 60 U.S. and partner nations students
text:
JOINT BASE SAN ANTONIO-LACKLAND, Texas -- More than 60 international military students from seven partner nations and the USAF filled an auditorium here for a ceremony to mark the end of their training at the Inter-American Air Forces Academy, April 26. Students graduated from eight courses in professional military education and leadership, aircrew training and technical courses.
Senior leaders, distinguished visitors and guests helped commemorate the event that also celebrated the academyâ€™s 80th anniversary. This year, the affair was held at the University of Incarnate Wordâ€™s Rosenburg Sky Room to mark the special celebration. Luis Moreno, former Ambassador to Jamaica, and former Narcotics Affairs Director in Bogota, Colombia, served as guest of honor. Moreno spoke of the importance of IAAFA in Latin America, and congratulated graduates on their achievement, which he said would most likely remember as â€œa bright arch in their livesâ€.
â€œIâ€™d like to extend my gratitude to our instructors, who each day not only led us to acquire knowledge in each of our courses, but for being true professionals and serving as fundamental pillars for us as students,â€ said Mayor Juan Verdugo of the Chilean Air Force who spoke at the graduation ceremony.
Col. Lauren Courchaine, 37th Training Wing Commander, Moreno and Capitan Jhonatan D. Escuraina Novoa of the Colombian Army performed the ceremonial cake cutting as the recipient of the General Fernando Melgar Award, an outstanding student recognition.
Escuraina, who also received the Academic Achievement Award in the officer category, and other top performing students were recognized during the banquet including Tecnico Segundo Luis Mejia De La Hoz from the Colombian Air Force, who earned the Academic Achievement Award for the highest-grade point average in the enlisted category.
Looking back at IAAFAâ€™s history, Col. JosÃ© JimÃ©nez, Jr., IAAFA commandant, spoke of the academyâ€™s eight decades of success as symbolizing new roles and opportunities for the institution as it charges forward and tackles new complex challenges. â€œAs we step into the new chapters of our journeys, let us work together to build cross cultural and cross boundary partnerships to advance common goals, cultivate, deepen shared relationships, accelerate change and preserve peace and human rights,â€ JimÃ©nez said.
â€œAs my time at the institution comes to an end, I am filled with hope as Iâ€™ve caught a glimpse of what the next generation of security cooperation professionals will achieve in the coming decades.â€

author: Oluseyi Taiwo-Oguntuase
title: Farm Junction Set To Address Post-Harvest Losses  | Independent Newspaper Nigeria
text: Farm Junction Set To Address Post-Harvest Losses As part of efforts to tackle the challenge of marketing and post-harvest losses usually experience by farmers across the country, an initiative to link farmers with consumers have been birthed. The initiative, Farm Junction is expected to bring the stakeholders in the agricultural value chain under an umbrella with the intention of bringing them to the consumers or exporters who need their produce. Yinka Omogoye, the Managing Director of Farm Junction at a stakeholders meeting in collaboration with the Lagos State Agricultural Development Authority (LSADA), said that the initiative will provide support structure for farmers to address waste by providing storage facility, packaging, transportation, logistics to farmers at minimal cost, thereby increasing their return on investment. He said that will encourage them to farm more and that will guarantee food security for Lagos in the immediate and for the nation at large. â€œThe time has come where we will take our future in our hands and the only way to do that is to secure our food. Food security is the only way to curb every other menace that is mitigating us as a people. READ ALSO: Farming Season: Al-Makura Distributes 3,000 Bags Of Fertilizer, Insecticide, Others To His Constituency â€œIf we have food security every other thing will fall in line, so for farmers donâ€™t be afraid go to your farm to produce, bring it to us we will off take from you, process for you and we will present your product or produce to the people that will buy and pay you your money. Engr. Alade Adewale, Programme Manager, Lagos State Agricultural Development Authority, in his remarks said that the collaboration intends to ensure that there is market for the farmers. He said the stakeholders meeting is also an avenue to ask the farmers what their problems are. â€œWe donâ€™t want to assume their problem, we want to hear from them directly what their issues and problems are so that when we hear from them we will find solution to their problem. He advised the farmers to take advantage of the collaboration. â€œWe are collaborating to ensure that there is market for farmers so that they can produce process and add value and have markets for their products then the farmers will be encouraged to produce more. Babatunde Wilkey, Managing Director of Meat Embassy while responding to the initiative admitted that it is a good initiative that will help the masses. He said the gesture will bring farmers, sellers, processors, consumers and the likes together under a platform which will in turn force the prices of products to come down as much as possible. â€œThere is power in synergy, the beauty of everything in life is the numbers when we come together as one definitely we will be able to control the market. He advised the government to provide an avenue where all farmers, processors can bring whatever they are producing to a hub where Nigerians can have access to buy things at a very cheapest price â€œWe need a platform where all of us can come together and showcase what we are selling to the whole Nigerian and it should not be limited to Lagos state every other state should do likewise,â€ he said Abiodun Oyelekan, one of the farmers present at the meeting commended the initiative stating that the major challenge that farmers encountered is marketing, that when there is an organization taking up the responsibility giving a link from the farm straight to the market it means farmers donâ€™t have problem again to produce. He said with the initiative farmers in the state will not have the challenge of marketing or where to sell their produce because when they produce they have already market for whatever they produce. Shakin Agbayewa, the Deputy Chairman, All Farmers Association of Nigeria, (AFAN), Lagos State Chapter stated that the initiative is good, that farmers in the state have been having issues with selling with produce, especially the perishables. He said one of the challenges is storage facility that it is because farmers donâ€™t have access to storage facilities that members of the association are being encouraged to add value to their produce. He said now that farm junction is trying to aggregate farmers together and assist with storage facility the challenge will be addressed.
